column4: hey for compiling new kernel all i need are the kernel-image and kernel-headers files from the repos right?
nope --- install the tree
kernel-tree-2.6.XX
yep, you might need to make a soft link to a "/usr/src/linux" dir, though
like this: ln -s /usr/src/linux-2.6.XX-ubuntu... /usr/src/linux
from an apt-cache search linux-tree:  linux-tree-2.6.12 - Linux kernel tree for building prepackaged Ubuntu kernel images
make sure you have kernel-package installed . . .
should be okay then .. . actually make sure you install build-essential
do you have a problem, or is it just a general kind of dammit . . .
no.  you would have to do that manually.
there are a few "custom" kernels via synaptic (e.g. 686, K7, etc. . .)
yeah, whatever works.  The only custom compile I "did" was when hoary had the 2 minute delay because of the KT400 chipset
yep... there is a wiki page on how to actually do it. . .
though it is pretty easy. . .  cd /usr/src ; sudo make oldconfig; make menuconfig (change stuff you want) ; sudo make-kpkg --append-to-version=custom kernel
that last command should be: make-kpkg --append-to-versio=custom kernel_image
too much wine . . . blame the wife
have you tried hdparm?
well, that is definitely a pain . . . are you using SATA?
try using "sudo hdparm /dev/hda1"  (or whatever hdX partition you need)
probably a motherboard issue.
I had tons of problems with my GA-7VAXP before 2.6.
you could always do an: hdparm -t -T /dev/whatever, then turn it off and try it again and compare results
then I guess it isn't working ;s
